articles.headline: September, November: 40 Precious Days to Spend on Early Vote
articles.snippet: A stream of voters arrived at election offices across Iowa to cast their ballots, and waves of absentee ballots have started landing in mailboxes in 30 other states.
articles.abstract: A stream of voters arrived at election offices across Iowa to cast their ballots, and waves of absentee ballots have started landing in mailboxes in 30 other states.
articles.lead_paragraph: 1:21 a.m. | Updated DES MOINES — A stream of voters arrived at election offices across Iowa to cast their ballots. Waves of absentee ballots have started landing in mailboxes in 30 other states. And more than a month before what the calendar says is Election Day, President Obama began delivering his closing argument to voters.

articles.headline: Greece Seeks Taxes From Wealthy With Cash Havens in London
articles.snippet: Greece, heavily in debt and desperate to track down money, is asking British authorities about investments by Greeks in expensive real estate.
articles.abstract: Greece, heavily in debt and desperate to track down money, is asking British authorities about investments by Greeks in expensive real estate.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — The London real estate market was abuzz. A wealthy Greek banker wanted to spend up to £60 million (nearly $100 million) for a home, and was in a hurry to make a deal.

articles.headline: Nod to Obama by Netanyahu in Warning to Iran on Bomb
articles.snippet: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel told the United Nations that Iran’s bomb-making ability will be irreversible by next year, but he also praised President Obama following a dispute over Iran policy.
articles.abstract: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel told the United Nations that Iran’s bomb-making ability will be irreversible by next year, but he also praised President Obama following a dispute over Iran policy.
articles.lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel told the United Nations on Thursday that Iran’s capability to enrich uranium must be stopped before next spring or early summer, arguing that by that time the country will be in a position to make a short, perhaps undetectable, sprint to manufacture its first nuclear weapon.
articles.byline: By Rick Gladstone and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: The Myth of Fixing the Libor
articles.snippet: It is unlikely that the London interbank offered rate can be repaired, no matter what Britain’s top financial regulator asserts.
articles.abstract: It is unlikely that the London interbank offered rate can be repaired, no matter what Britain’s top financial regulator asserts.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sometimes modern finance has a great need for something, and so bankers invent products that appear to fill that need. When it turns out that the invention was actually something else entirely, people are shocked.

articles.headline: Fearing Fiscal Cliff, Investors Cash In and Seek Safety
articles.snippet: Investors are bracing for what might happen after the election, when politicians will have to negotiate a deal on tax cuts and the deficit or face automatic cuts.
articles.abstract: Investors are bracing for what might happen after the election, when politicians will have to negotiate a deal on tax cuts and the deficit or face automatic cuts.
articles.lead_paragraph: After riding a quarter-long rally fueled by central bankers in Europe and the United States, investors are taking a more defensive posture on fears that politicians could derail the momentum.

articles.headline: Ammunition for a Trade War Between U.S. and Mexico
articles.snippet: The Department of Commerce took steps to end a 16-year-old agreement with Mexico that makes Mexican tomatoes a bargain in American supermarkets.
articles.abstract: The Department of Commerce took steps to end a 16-year-old agreement with Mexico that makes Mexican tomatoes a bargain in American supermarkets.
articles.lead_paragraph: Estimates are that nearly one out of two tomatoes eaten in the United States comes from Mexico — a statistic Florida growers would like to change, even at the risk of a trade war.
articles.byline: By Stephanie Strom and Elisabeth Malkin

articles.headline: United States Economy Still Weak, but More Feel Secure
articles.snippet: A closely watched measure of consumer confidence surged to its highest level since February, even as job growth and the overall economy had weakened.
articles.abstract: A closely watched measure of consumer confidence surged to its highest level since February, even as job growth and the overall economy had weakened.
articles.lead_paragraph: Both economists and the Romney campaign are puzzling over the same paradox: The recovery has flagged and yet the country’s mood appears to be improving.

articles.headline: Veterans Wait for Benefits as Claims Pile Up
articles.snippet: A crushing inventory of claims for disability, pension and educational benefits has overwhelmed the Department of Veterans Affairs.
articles.abstract: A crushing inventory of claims for disability, pension and educational benefits has overwhelmed the Department of Veterans Affairs.
articles.lead_paragraph: For Dennis Selsky, a Vietnam-era veteran with multiple sclerosis, it was lost documents. It seemed that every time he sent records to the Department of Veterans Affairs, they disappeared into the ether.

articles.headline: U.S. Is Tightening Web Privacy Rule to Shield Young
articles.snippet: Federal regulations intended to curb the collection of data from young Internet users without their parents’ permission might cause companies to stop creating child-centric sites.
articles.abstract: Federal regulations intended to curb the collection of data from young Internet users without their parents’ permission might cause companies to stop creating child-centric sites.
articles.lead_paragraph: Federal regulators are about to take the biggest steps in more than a decade to protect children online.

articles.headline: Enrollment Drops Again in Graduate Programs
articles.snippet: After surges in enrollment in 2008 and 2009, the number of students entering graduate schools declined last year for the second year in a row.
articles.abstract: After surges in enrollment in 2008 and 2009, the number of students entering graduate schools declined last year for the second year in a row.
articles.lead_paragraph: Enrollment in college is still climbing, but students are increasingly saying no to graduate school in the United States.

articles.headline: Bank of America Settles Suit Over Merrill for $2.43 Billion
articles.snippet: Bank of America announced on Friday that it would pay $2.43 billion to settle a class action lawsuit related to its acquisition of Merrill Lynch.
articles.abstract: Bank of America announced on Friday that it would pay $2.43 billion to settle a class action lawsuit related to its acquisition of Merrill Lynch.
articles.byline: By Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Susanne Craig

articles.headline: Perspective Is at Play in Who Is ‘Better Off’
articles.snippet: Those who have done well don’t seem more likely to vote for President Obama, and those with less money appear to be least likely to vote for Mitt Romney.
articles.abstract: Those who have done well don’t seem more likely to vote for President Obama, and those with less money appear to be least likely to vote for Mitt Romney.
articles.lead_paragraph: “This president cannot tell us that you are better off today than when he took office,” Mitt Romney said as he accepted the Republican presidential nomination. Since then, “Are you better off?” has become a central theme of the campaign, and is likely to surface next week at the first presidential debate.
